Regular work flow

Request has been made to create a new navigation in the header of the site, this will be a new feature

master > (new branch) feature/new-navigation-menu > (merge) dev > (merge) staging > (merge) master

  1. Create new branch from master called feature/new-navigation-menu
  2. Commit work as you go
  3. Once work is ready to show PM merge into dev
  4. Once PM has approved merge into staging for client
  5. Once Client has approved merge to master for production

Regular work flow with PM change

The navigation doesnt work in ie 11, switch back to feature/new-navigation-menu and fix the issue, merge to dev for PM approval

(change to) feature/new-navigation-menu > (merge) dev > (merge) staging > (merge) master

  1. Switch to feature/new-navigation-menu
  2. Fix issue
  3. Once work is ready to show PM merge into dev
  4. Once PM has approved merge into staging for client
  5. Once Client has approved merge to master for production

Urgent hotfix

Classified as "site down, needs immediate attention to continue to run"

master > (branch) hotfix/iis-webconfig-update > (merge) master

  1. Create new branch from master called hotfix/iis-webconfig-update
  2. Solve issue, if it needs testing go to dev, otherwise deploy direct to master

Branch naming strategy

feature/#ticketnumber: for new features or code additions

hotfix/#ticketnumber: for urgent fixes required for production to continue to work

chore/#ticketnumber: deprecation of code, refactoring or package updates

Writing good commit messages

What usually happens...

#1 rule, give context for the code reviewer. Making a commit message saying "updated css file" gives no context at a high level to people reviewing code. "updated navigation with new hover effect" will allow a reviewer to track down code changes and debug easier.

Examples of good commit messages

  • added loading icon for contact and login form
  • updated packages in npm to fix security holes
  • removed deprecated code from cart api and cleaned up implementation

Why? descriptive, outline issue or feature in one sentance, direct

Examples of bad commit messages

  • fixed issue
  • updated css files and minified js
  • dammit i hate ie

Why? opinionated, non descriptive, venting, reviewer has no idea what this commit does
